title: Introduction to Category Theory
description: A CE-structured course demonstrating learning as manifold climbing

domains.name: Basic Concepts
domains.description: Foundational ideas that build the category-theoretic worldview

concepts.name: Category
concepts.content: A category consists of objects and morphisms between them. Categories capture the structure of mathematical relationships. Every category has identity morphisms and composition is associative.

concepts.name: Morphism
concepts.content: A morphism is a structure-preserving map between objects. Morphisms compose associatively. Identity morphisms act as units for composition.

concepts.name: Functor
concepts.content: A functor is a morphism between categories. It preserves composition and identity. Functors allow us to translate structure between categories.

domains.name: Advanced Topics
domains.description: Deeper structures that emerge from basic concepts

concepts.name: Natural Transformation
concepts.content: A natural transformation is a morphism between functors. It provides a way to relate functors while respecting the structure of categories. Natural transformations are the morphisms in the category of functors.

concepts.name: Adjunction
concepts.content: An adjunction is a relationship between two functors that captures a universal property. Adjunctions are fundamental to understanding how categories relate to each other. They provide a way to translate between different categorical perspectives.
